We must be brave. It is about time the precedent set yesterday by the chief executive of Bank of Ireland's competitor bank, who took a reduction of 15% from the capped ceiling, was followed.
The Taoiseach, who spends every single day, from 6 a.m. until midnight, working for the people of this country is on a fraction of the salaries and pensions of people in the banking sector.
Deputy Mathews's time has expired.
Who recommended to the shareholders Mr. Boucher's remuneration and that of the other executives of the bank?
The board of the bank.
To clarify then, Mr. Boucher recommended his own salary.
I cannot recommend my own salary.
Mr. Boucher is on the board of the bank. He is the chief executive of the board.
I did not recommend my own salary.
Who recommended it?
I did not participate in the discussion of a recommendation of the remuneration committee on my own salary.
The board, of which Mr. Boucher is a member-----
People absent themselves when their individual salaries are discussed by the board.

Does Mr. Boucher feel any discomfort whatsoever when his bank is involved in repossessing homes or putting extreme pressure on people to pay mortgage arrears that they cannot manage, many of whom are in difficulties because of the activities of banks like BOI, while he is earning in excess of half a million euro per year? Can he understand why people are angry about that?
My remuneration is put to the shareholders on an annual basis.
So, it does not bother Mr. Boucher one way or the other if people are concerned about it.
I would not presume that.
What role did Mr. Boucher play, if any, in the Jurys Doyle deal, involving Sean Dunne?
We do not discuss individual customers.
Mr. Boucher cannot tell us if he played any role in that deal, is that correct?
I will not discuss individual customers.
Okay. We are not getting very far here, are we?
How much would it cost to write down the mortgage accounts that are in negative equity?
The disclosure on negative equity-----
How much would it cost to write them down to current market levels?
I am sorry Deputy, my colleague will have to look up that data. I will answer that question in a moment but will answer other questions in the meantime.
That is fine. How many mortgage accounts does Bank of Ireland have?
We have 198,000 mortgage accounts, although that does not equate to the number of customers. We have approximately 160,000 mortgage customers.
So, in answer to the question Mr. Boucher could not answer, the bank has approximately 15,000 mortgage accounts in arrears, according to my rough calculations.
The value of negative equity in our book disclosed on 30 June is €4.3 billion.
I ask Mr. Boucher to repeat that.
The value is approximately €4.3 billion. I am rounding up. The exact amount is €4.286 billion.

Why would Bank of Ireland not consider writing off that negative equity, which would put the vast majority of approximately 16,000 mortgage holders who are in arrears into a sustainable position? It would also put those whose accounts have already been restructured into a more favourable position whereby they could free themselves of a huge debt burden sooner. Why would Bank of Ireland not consider writing off the negative equity, which would help the country and the tens of thousands of distressed mortgage holders, many of whom are in distress through no fault of their own? Indeed, some of the distress was caused by the activities of Bank of Ireland.

The value of negative equity is not necessarily a correlation to cash flow at default. Of the €4.3 billion, approximately €3.3 billion at the end of June was neither past due nor impaired. The value of negative equity either past due or impaired is €800 million.

Bank of Ireland is claiming success because it has restructured quite a lot of mortgages. However, as Deputy Higgins has pointed out, a lot of those people are in pretty miserable circumstances, even though they may just be able to manage the restructuring arrangement the bank has agreed with them. The bank has the whip hand, let us be honest. However, it is not a very good situation and it means that such people are trapped in a pretty awful debt situation for a very long time to come. In addition, if I understand correctly, there are approximately 16,000 restructured mortgages and all of those people would not be in restructured arrangements were they not in some difficulty. Most of that difficulty arose from the bubble period and the consequences of the property crash. In addition, approximately 9.22% of the bank's overall mortgage book is in arrears and that figure is rising, year on year. It has risen from 5.89% in June 2011 to 9.22% this year, which is a very dramatic increase.

I advised the committee in my opening remarks that at the end of August, when we were announcing our 30 June results, we perceived that the pace of arrears was abating and that continues to be the case.
The pace of arrears is abating?
Yes.
According to these figures, the number of mortgage loans in arrears in June 2011 was 5.89% of the mortgage book but one year later the number is 9.22%.
Yes, but as I have said, the pace is abating.
That does not sound like an abating pace to me. It has risen from 5.89% to 9.22% in one year and Mr. Boucher is saying that indicates a slow down in mortgage distress.
I am indicating where the trajectory is on a quarter by quarter basis.
I would put it to Mr. Boucher that it is not a situation which looks like it is improving. There has been an increase of nearly four percentage points-----
We have a significant challenges in managing our mortgage book and I fully acknowledge that.

It is a very significant challenge. I estimate that Bank of Ireland has 32,000 mortgage customers who are either in restructured arrangements or in arrears now and a significant number of additional customers who are getting into distress. Mr. Boucher says that the problem is slowing but I do not see the evidence for that. Why does the bank not consider writing off the unsustainable portions of these debts that arose during an exceptional period, namely a property bubble, which Bank of Ireland helped to stoke up?
Where would the money come from?
It would come from the money the bank was given, namely, the recapitalisation money.

We were not given any money. That is all invested and people expect a return. As I pointed out, Deputy, we have very few subordinated bonds left and a significant amount of capital was generated from the ECB.
Mr. Boucher said earlier that there is gratitude towards the Irish taxpayer for assisting the bank. Did I pick up that remark correctly?
Yes, we got support from the taxpayer.
Bank of Ireland would feel a certain amount of gratitude for that, is that correct?
Yes.

Does Mr. Boucher think there should be a dividend as an expression of that gratitude? I put it to him that he should re-engage with the Minister for Arts, Heritage and the Gaeltacht in regard to the bank premises on College Green. Tourism has a major role to play in Ireland and if the State had control over Grattan's Parliament, it would help us to develop our tourism industry. If the bank is not prepared to do that, I ask Mr. Boucher to consider a building swap with the Central Bank further up the street. I am simply asking him to consider the matter and am not looking for an answer now.

The primary responsibility we have is to reduce the risk to the taxpayer and to give a cash return to the taxpayer. However, as I mentioned earlier, we are prepared to look at any asset of the group on an ongoing basis.
I would ask Mr. Boucher to re-engage with the Minister.
If someone comes to us with a proposal which is commercially sensible, we will look at it.
Is 62% of Bank of Ireland's mortgage book in trackers?
Yes.
Bank of Ireland sets variable interest rates on mortgages. What role does an opinion poll play in setting those rates?
An opinion poll from where?
Does Bank of Ireland use polls from RED C and such organisations in setting rates?
We have customers on an ongoing basis. These include borrowers who want to pay at the lowest rate possible and depositors who want to get paid the highest rate possible.
I am asking whether the setting of rates is technical. Does Bank of Ireland get an opinion poll on whether it should increase rates?
The setting of any rates is primarily designed by our long-term franchise, how our rates compare and whether they cover the cost of the raw material.
It is a "Yes" or "No" question. Would Bank of Ireland really use an opinion poll to set rates?
I am not sure what I would ask the customers. If I were to ask customers whether they would like to pay less, I imagine they would.
It is a technical process of how the market stands. That is grand.
The question is peculiar.
It is going somewhere. I will leave it for one minute.
Okay, I will leave it with you. You are like Columbo. You have one more question.
Can I have two more questions? I have not gone over three minutes.
We have plenty of time.
Does Bank of Ireland set targets for mortgage advisers to reduce the number of its trackers?
No, the job of our mortgage advisers relates to where a customer is in arrears. New business mortgage advisers sell our products but we do not sell trackers as products.

Bank of Ireland wrote to several of its customers in October and sought to share information in respect of a RED C opinion poll. To me it seems like trying to trick people off trackers. The letter from Bank of Ireland implies that there are better products available and that Bank of Ireland will be in contact. If the only information relates to RED C research, does that amount to misleading Bank of Ireland customers about tracker mortgages? Is Mr. Boucher aware of this letter?

We look at the demand for certain types of products on an ongoing basis. We perceive that interest rates are relatively low in the market whereas the cost of money to the bank is high. The take-up of fixed rate mortgages in Ireland is low. Should interest rates rise then the customers and the bank are exposed.

There was an ugly face of banking previously and I would hate to think we are going back that way. The beginning of the letter states that the bank wishes to share with its valued mortgage customers some interesting findings from research carried out recently among similar homeowners who have mortgages on a tracker rate. The research was conducted by RED C in August in 2012. To be honest, from reading the letter it appears to try to trick people with tracker mortgages into engaging with the bank to move to lesser or higher interest rate mortgages. To me that is the ugly face of banking that we have seen.
Do you wish to read the letter into the record, Deputy?
I will do so at a later stage. Is Mr. Boucher aware of the letter? Did he approve it?

I did not approve it but I am aware that on an ongoing basis we look to see whether there is a demand for fixed-rate products. If there is a demand for fixed-rate products then we buy the money in the market to try to switch them.
Mr. Boucher is saying there is a better fixed-rate product on the market than current tracker mortgages.
The Deputy-----

Let me finish the question. Tracker mortgages are currently between 1.75% and 2.75%, assuming 1 percentage point above the base rate. Is there a better package than that at the moment? Does Bank of Ireland have a better package at the moment?
It depends on one's view of long-term interest rates.

In the medium term tracker mortgages are the best for Bank of Ireland customers. Mr. Boucher stated earlier that trackers are non-profitable. It is in Bank of Ireland's interest to try to push people off trackers. To me RED C data is not something that should be used to make a decision on what interest rates one pays.
When a customer looks to switch a mortgage from a tracker to a fixed-rate-----
They are not looking to do that. Bank of Ireland is looking for them to switch.
We are doing research on the demand for fixed rate products.
Mr. Boucher referred to when a customer wants to change but the bank is looking for the customer to change. The customer is not looking to change.
We are trying to ascertain the demand for fixed-rate products. We try to design our products a certain way because we must buy the money in the marketplace.

I put it to Mr. Boucher that Bank of Ireland is trying to trick or push people on tracker mortgages onto a higher interest rate mortgage. This will push more people into debt stress. I do not believe Bank of Ireland is acting in good faith with these customers. I put that to Mr. Boucher directly.
From our perspective we have to try to ascertain the demand for fixed-rate products because we have to go and buy the money.
Deputy Humphreys, if you wish to make such a statement I will have to ask you to put the letter on the record.
I take it that will not be part of my time at this stage.
I will allow you to go through it.
The letter states:

As a valued mortgage customer we want to share some interesting findings from research that we have carried out recently with homeowners like you who have a mortgage on a tracker rate. The data conducted by RED C in August 2012 on behalf of the Bank of Ireland found that customers on tracker rates believe that lower payments and rates of interest are the most appealing feature of their mortgage. A significant proportion, 75%, of our customers with tracker rates believe the ECB rate will increase in the next five years. The majority of customers, 84%, are concerned about the resulting increase in mortgage repayments. If, like these customers, you have concerns about increasing mortgage repayments we may have options that can afford you more certainty of repayments at affordable rates, giving you the benefits your current low rate but without the risk of increases over the next five years.

The letter continues: "We will be calling you over the next week to discuss the options and to answer any questions you may have. If this timeframe is inconvenient...we will contact you...please contact the following phone number." The date of the letter is October 2012.

I will summarise my reading of the letter. Deputy Humphreys, you are saying that the letter gives the impression that the variable rates will be better when measured against tracker rates at some time in future. Is that correct?
At this stage we are all aware that tracker rates are the most advantageous. Will Bank of Ireland publish or make available the questions put out by RED C to get this information?
We will make that available.
Will Bank of Ireland supply the questionnaire and the results?
Yes.
Is Bank of Ireland satisfied that this letter was sent out in this matter?

The nature and background of the letter relates to research we did with customers on ECB rates in the coming years and they are an important element of a tracker rate. The feedback from customers was that ECB rates would increase in the next five years. As Mr. Boucher said, we are trying to ascertain customer interest in fixed-rates to protect against an increase in ECB rates.
The letter states that Bank of Ireland has better packages. Does Bank of Ireland have better packages than the current ECB tracker?
It depends on the movement of interest rates.
Does Bank of Ireland have a better rate than 2.75%?
We cannot guarantee 2.75% but we can guarantee a fixed rate.
Mr. Boucher said that it depends but I am asking if there is a higher rate if one has a tracker. Is there a better package than 2.75%?
The fixed rate takes into consideration that the market believes the rates will increase in future and therefore the cost is higher, but it provides protection.
Does Bank of Ireland have a better rate than 2.75%?
It is a different product. By its definition, a variable rate product is-----

It is somewhat like the packages one gets for a telephone or mobile phone. I have asked the question and Mr. Boucher understands it. Overall, does Bank of Ireland have a better rate than the 2.75% rate? The person that brought this letter to me believes that he was being tricked to engage with the bank to come off his tracker rate. That is a reasonably fair interpretation of the letter.
There is no intention to trick. This was in response to customer concerns raised in recent research about the ECB element of their tracker rate.
Did Bank of Ireland send these letters to those with buy-to-let trackers?
We sent it to a small number of customers as part of a pilot.

Did Bank of Ireland send it to those with buy-to-let trackers or was it simply sent to ordinary people who own their own homes and who have trackers? Did Bank of Ireland send it to people with buy-to-let mortgages?
We sent it to no more than 300 customers from a book of 198,000. I simply do not have the information to hand on the composition of who got it.
Were all the recipients tracker holders?
Yes.
I think it is unfortunate. I believe Bank of Ireland is putting pressure on people or trying to convince them to move away from trackers.
I ask the Deputy to place a redacted copy of that correspondence before the committee. We do not need the individual's name and address, but a copy of the letter would be useful.
I will give it to the clerk.
Following up on the point made by Deputy Kevin Humphreys, what is the bank's current five-year fixed mortgage rate?
It is in the region of 4.3% to 4.5%.

My understanding from the figures is that there is just over €17 billion in outstanding tracker loans and just over €10 billion in outstanding non-tracker loans on Bank of Ireland's mortgage book in the Republic. With rounding, this comes to some €28 billion in outstanding mortgage loans. The figure given for the amount of negative equity was €4.3 billion. Does that figure apply only to the Republic?
Yes, that figure relates to the Republic of Ireland.
In other words, therefore, it is the bank's estimate that of the €28 billion in loans outstanding, there is some €23.7 billion, give or take, of real assets at market value.
It is a mark-in-time estimate.
As of today.
As at 30 June, based on an indexation of the peak to trough loan-to-value ratio and the origination profile which we disclosed in our 30 June statements.

Is Mr. Boucher saying the bank's best estimate at the time is that against the approximately €28 billion in mortgages outstanding in the Republic of Ireland, there are realisable assets at today's market value of just under €24 billion?
It is a different thing. The measure of negative equity at a point in time is €4.3 billion. Whether that would be realisable if all of the mortgages came to the market, I do not know.
How does the bank calculate negative equity if not as the difference between the amount outstanding versus realisable assets?
It is an indexation based on the CSO's assessment of the move in house prices. We look at the origination time and the amount advanced at origination. That is different from realisable value.

Does that mean the €4.3 billion in negative equity is not the bank's estimate of the difference between the total amount of mortgages outstanding and the total amount of asset value against those loans?
The disclosure is the negative equity.
Will Mr. Boucher answer the question?

The disclosure is the negative equity. That is what we do; we do not do a realisable value. The vast majority of our mortgages are being repaid on time. Customers are able to meet their obligations and a primary assessment of our ability to have mortgages repaid is the customer's ability. We do not see a correlation between negative equity and ability to repay.

I am not talking about ability to repay. I am trying to understand whether, when he says "negative equity", Mr. Boucher means the difference between the total amount of loans outstanding and the realisable assets against those loans. If someone has a mortgage of €500,000, for example, and the market value of the property is €300,000, the negative equity is €200,000, that is, the difference between the loan outstanding and the market value of the asset.
We also take into account an assessment of the customer's cash flow over the lifetime of the mortgage.
That is not applicable to the negative equity.
The current estimate of the customer's ability to repay is the estimate of the cash flow the customer has over a period of time. The security is different.

Using the same example of a mortgage of €500,000 against a property that is worth €300,000, is Mr. Boucher saying the €200,000 difference between the mortgage and the asset value is not what he means by negative equity?
We are disclosing what the negative equity is based on the origination of the mortgage and indexation during that time.
I understand. Will Mr. Boucher answer the question I asked?
I have given the answer. That is what we disclose in our accounts as negative equity. I cannot give any other answer.

I go back again to the example of an outstanding mortgage of €500,000 and a current market value of €300,000. Putting it very simply, would the bank consider the negative equity in that case to be €200,000? I ask Mr. Boucher to answer either "Yes" or "No".

If the negative equity is the €4.3 billion on the book, based on indexation across all mortgages, on an individual basis, the answer is "Yes". However, the customer's ability to repay is different from the security piece. We assess on the basis of a customer's ability to repay. This is not a pawnbroking business. We look at the customer's ability to repay.

I understand, but there seems to be a very clear difference of opinion. My understanding of negative equity is that if a person owes the bank €500,000 and his or her asset is worth €300,000, whether he or she is on the dole or earning €1 million per year, that loan has a negative equity of €200,000 attached to it.
We are talking about a potential negative equity at a point in time.
A potential negative equity.
Yes. There is a potential negative equity based on a statistical review of the book.

In the context of the figure of €4.3 billion provided by the bank and sticking with our example of a loan of €500,000 on a property with a market value of €300,000, am I right in saying there is a risk assessment of the ability to repay and the declared negative equity is adjusted accordingly?

No, we look at the customer's ability to repay. Our primary focus in all of our lending is on the customer's cash flow. In certain of our products we have different types of security and we assess that security on an ongoing basis.
If someone-----
Is Mr. Boucher saying negative equity is the bank's view of the ability-----
Deputy Donnelly is in possession.
Going back to the example of an outstanding mortgage of €500,000 and a market value of €300,000, is there any situation where that will not be recorded as negative equity of €200,000?
The disclosure in the accounts is the negative equity across the entire portfolio, based on the assumption-----
With respect, I ask Mr. Boucher to stop repeating the same sentence and engage with the question I am asking.
I am giving the answer based on our accounts.
Will Mr. Boucher give me an example based on a single instance?
I am giving the Deputy the disclosures in our accounts.
Will Mr. Boucher answer the question I asked him?
I have given the answer I can give the Deputy.
Mr. Boucher is not willing to engage with reference to a single example.
I can give the answers based on the disclosures in our accounts.
I shall try to ask the question in a different way. Of the €28 billion of outstanding mortgages in the Republic, what is the bank's estimate of the current market value against that loan book?
That is not an estimate we provide.
Is Mr. Boucher saying the bank does not have an estimate of the asset value of its domestic mortgages?
We do not mark-to-market our book. It is a lending book, not a trading book.
Mr. Boucher is stating the bank does not have an estimate of the asset value against domestic mortgages.
We do not mark-to-market lending books.
The answer to my question, then, is "No".
The answer to the question is that we do not mark-to-market lending books.
Will Mr. Boucher put that in layman's terms, for the benefit of those listening at home to this discussion? Does he have an estimate of the total value of the domestic loan book?

We have an estimate of the total value of the loan book based on the provisions we make against when a loan is impaired or in default. We disclose these provisions. We expect the vast majority of our customers-----

I apologise for interrupting. As I can barely follow the discussion, I am concerned about how listeners at home are faring. Is Deputy Donnelly referring to the bank's mortgage lend book or the total lend book?
I am referring to the mortgage book, which is estimated at €28 billion.
Thank you, Deputy. I invite Mr. Boucher to continue.

It is a lending book. We assess the customer's ability to pay and look at his or her cash flow. We disclose on an ongoing basis if a customer is going to be impaired. However, we expect the vast majority of our book to be repaid. It is a lending book. As such, it is an assessment of potential future cash flow, security in a default and assumptions made on the basis of that security.
What level of impairment has the bank put against the €28 billion?
The provision at 30 June was €1.4 billion.
The last time Mr. Boucher appeared before the committee, he told us that the total amount which Bank of Ireland had surrendered in terms of mortgage debt in the Republic of Ireland was zero.
Is that still the case?
We do not give market disclosure figures.
Mr. Boucher gave the market disclosure figure on the previous occasion on which he came before us.
We do not give market disclosure figures beyond what is included in our accounts.
Therefore, Mr. Boucher is refusing to state how much money, if any, the bank has surrendered, even though he did so on the previous occasion on which he appeared before the committee.
We do not give market disclosure figures beyond what is included in our accounts.
Therefore, Mr. Boucher is refusing to supply the information in question. I will ask a different question. Is the amount Bank of Ireland has surrendered in its accounts?
The provisions against our books-----
That is not what I am asking. I am asking whether the total amount the bank has surrendered in its accounts. Does the bank now disclose it?
Our accounts provide for full disclosure in accordance with accounting standards and regulatory standards of what we are and are not required to disclose.
I understand that. Will Mr. Boucher actually answer the question I asked?
The disclosure is the provision.
The disclosure is the provision.
The Deputy is going to run out of time. I appreciate, however, that the responses being provided by Mr. Boucher are not assisting him in that regard.

Just for the record, Mr. Boucher, as chief executive of Bank of Ireland, is refusing to tell the Oireachtas Joint Committee on Finance, Public Expenditure and Reform how much the bank has surrendered. Bank of Ireland has taken a write-down of €1.4 billion. Deputy Pearse Doherty asked how much had been-----
I outlined the position on the provision.

Yes, I understand. The bank has made a provision of €1.4 billion. On the previous occasion on which he was before the committee Mr. Boucher said the bank had not surrendered anything. He is now refusing to tell the committee what is the actual number. That is fine.
In terms of the personal insolvency legislation being brought forward-----
This will be the Deputy's final question.

I thank the Chairman. If someone enters into a debt settlement arrangement on secured debt, particularly in respect of a house, and if an agreement can be arrived at by the bank, the personal insolvency professional and the borrower or borrowers, at the end of the debt settlement period - under the proposed legislation this will be up to six years - is it the bank's understanding that the borrower or borrowers could keep the house? Is it also its understanding that, as part of a debt settlement arrangement, an amount of debt could be surrendered by the bank to the borrower or borrowers?

That depends on the terms of the debt settlement agreement. As it is a hypothetical question, it depends on the individual circumstances and an assessment of the future earning capacity of the customer.
Therefore, it is possible that the bank will engage in debt surrender as part of debt settlement agreements under the new legislation. Is that what Mr. Boucher is saying?
The bank's responsibility is to maximise the recoveries it makes from the loans it provides.

Yes, I understand that. We are in the Republic of Ireland and can state all sorts of truisms. I do not know what Mr. Boucher is doing here if he is refusing to answer questions. For the record, he is refusing to indicate to the Oireachtas Joint Committee on Finance, Public Expenditure and Reform whether the bank will even consider debt surrender in the context of the upcoming personal insolvency legislation. I thank him very much for his time. This has been a most illuminating experience.
I call Senator Barrett who has six minutes. I ask him to adhere to the time limits which apply in order that we might conclude proceedings somewhere near the appointed time.

I shall try to use even less time. The document with which we have been supplied indicates that the underlying loss between December 2011 and June 2012 increased from €722 million to €907 million, a rise of 24%. Therefore, the most recent figures supplied to the committee indicate that the position on the investment the taxpayer made - involuntarily - in September 2008 has depreciated by 24%. The document also indicates that impairment charges rose from €901 million in the first half of 2011 to €978 million in the same period in 2012. This is despite the fact that on page 8 of the document a statement is made to the effect that "Impairment charges below the level incurred in H2 2011 but remain elevated", whereas, in fact, they increased. A similar statement is made on page 13, namely, "Impairment charges remain elevated but have reduced from the level in H2 2011". Someone who stopped reading at page 8 or page 13 and did not read as far as page 26 would have obtained a completely different view of the position on impairment charges. Such charges have actually increased by 9% or €77 million.

We have provided a graph which shows the position in H1 and H2 2011 and H2 2012. On the basis of accounting convention and from a presentational point of view, we are obliged to report half-year on half-year. We also show the trajectory for the second half-year period. The graph tries to illustrate, clearly, what we are talking about.

The point I want to make is that the figure is increasing. Unlike the statements to which I refer on pages 8 and 13, when one reaches page 26, one realises that the amount rose by €77 million. The overall performance of the bank is also in decline and that is of concern to the people who made the investment, particularly in the context of the fact that the underlying loss increased from €722 million to €907 million.
I am concerned by the statement on page 9 to the effect that Bank of Ireland is 73% a property-based institution. That is exactly what got the country into the trouble in which it finds itself.
The Senator is going to run out of time, without Mr. Boucher being able to provide replies.
Will Mr. Boucher comment on the public interest directors at the bank? How much are these individuals paid? Do they make any contribution at all to solving the problems we are discussing?

The directors' remuneration is set out in the annual report. I do not have the information, but I can supply a page number. Under company law, the directors are all obliged to work in the best interests of the company. The Minister for Finance made an announcement in that regard in answer to a question in the Dáil. All the directors are expected to challenge and contribute to the board.
Does Senator Barrett wish to ask other questions?
No, I am finished with my questions. I am just listening for answers.
What makes public interest directors different from the other directors on the board?
They do not have to stand for re-election. That is the primary difference between them and the other directors. For that reason and under Stock Exchange rules, they are not considered independent.
Their primary client is the bank, it is not actually the State.
Under company law, they are required to act in the best interests of the company.
Therefore, they are not really personal interest directors, as such, particularly if they are required to obey the law.

If I might move from the particular to the general, Bank of Ireland's future is tied up with that of the country. We have a vested interest in the recovery of the country. Our business will not recover unless the country recovers. I suspect that we are 80% to 90% aligned in respect of these goals. We would have different-----

That is not the question Senator Barrett posed. He inquired as to what made personal interest directors different from other directors on the board. Mr. Boucher's response was that under company law, they were required to behave and display a duty of care in the same fashion as the other directors. They are not, therefore, really any different from the other directors.
They are not private interest directors; they are public interest directors.
They do not report to the State, the Minister for Finance or, under its terms of reference, this committee. This means that they are no different from the other directors.
The primary difference between them and the other directors is that they do not stand for re-election.

Which is a great position in which to be. In terms of their day-to-day work, they do not do anything different from the other directors. I would love to be in a position where I would not be obliged to stand for re-election at the conclusion of the term of each Dáil. However, that is not the way it works. There are rules to which the people concerned are obliged to adhere and, as such, there really is no difference between them and the other directors other than the fact that they are not obliged to stand for re-election.
All of the directors-----

I wish to make a proposal to the effect that we should call the public interest directors to come before us at the earliest opportunity. Is that agreed? Agreed. Does Senator Barrett wish to add anything?

I take it that the performance of the bank is declining, as shown on page 8, that the underlying losses are up to €907 million from €722 million and that the impairment charges are rising, as shown on page 26. Will Mr. Boucher confirm the figures?
Impairment charges are reducing on a half-year basis.
Then how come they go up by €77 million when one goes to page 26?
The systems go to page 30, which is the market disclosure. We disclose half year and half year and then against the preceding period.
This is exactly the half year period, H1 201 2 and H1 201 1. It went from €901 million to €978 million. I presume the numbers Mr. Boucher has supplied to us are correct.
They are verified numbers, taken from our annual report and statement.
How much time do I have?
Deputy O’Donnell has about six minutes and then I will call Deputy Ross. We will conclude at that point.

Limited time is available. I know Mr. Boucher well because I brought the CEOs of the banks before the finance committee in 2008. I am struck by their lack of moral compass. Nothing has changed although we are in a completely different space now. Mr. Boucher is not answering questions. I will put a couple of questions to him. First, have the top level CEOs in the banks taken any reduction in salary to date?
Yes.
When?
It was disclosed in the accounts in 2009.
Have any reductions been introduced since then?
There has been a reduction in my pension arrangements, as was publicly disclosed in 2010.
What pension is the former CEO, Mr. Brian Goggin, in receipt of currently?
I am not aware of that. I do not know.
It is publicly disclosed.
I can get the disclosure but I am not aware of it.
I think it is of the order of €300,000 but I hear someone say that it is €650,000.
I will get the exact disclosure.
Did the bank have a shortfall in its pension fund?
We have a deficit in the fund.
How is the bank funding that?
The deficit is an accounting deficit. It is driven by liabilities and measures. We look at the assets and the liabilities.
How is the bank funding the shortfall? The bank is required to fund the deficit in the pension scheme.

Over a period of time. Primarily, there has been a combination of a change in benefits which were agreed in 2010 and 2011, freezing of future payments and changing the liabilities and assets in the fund.
My question is whether any of the shortfall is being funded by the bank itself.
The bank has a contractual obligation to meet certain funds.

Is it correct to say that some taxpayers’ money that went into Bank of Ireland is going to fund the deficit on a pension scheme that is paying €650,000 to the CEO that was in place at the time the bank had to depend on the kindness of taxpayers to bail it out?
Yes, I think so. The money was from all the shareholders.
Am I correct in the assertion that Mr. Brian Goggin is on a higher pension than Mr. Boucher’s current salary?
Based on the information Deputy Ross has found, that is the case.
It is a pretty close run thing.
Second, if Mr. Boucher were to retire in the morning, under the rules of the scheme, what percentage of salary would be given by way of pension?
It is two thirds of final salary under defined benefit.
If one were to work on the basis of those figures, that is €620,000 divided by three and multiplied by two, which means he would be on a pension of more than €400,000.
Potentially, if I work until I reach my full benefit.
Given the situation, does Mr. Boucher not find that mind boggling? He has the distinction of being the only top level management CEO still in place from the time of the crisis.
When did Bank of Ireland introduce 100% mortgages for home owners?
I cannot recall exactly. I think it was early 2006.

In terms of the loans in arrears for more than 90 days I see a spike in 2006 and 2007. In 2005 it was 9.8%. In 2006 it was 12.3% and in 2007 it was 12.5%. Bank of Ireland is responsible for many of those people being in arrears. It is not good enough to come before the committee and say that the bank must recover the maximum amount of loans. The bank irresponsibly gave out 100% loans at that time. Has the bank given any write-offs to mortgage holders recently?
We have provided against the mortgages-----
No, I am asking whether write-offs have been provided to individuals.
I have given the answer I can give.
What is the total amount of money put into Bank of Ireland by taxpayers?
The total investment by the taxpayer is €4.8 billion. The sum of €0.5 billion-----

A portion of the €4.8 billion is funding a pension of €650,000 a year to Mr. Brian Goggin, former CEO, and the salary for Mr. Boucher, who was previously deputy CEO with responsibility for retail mortgages, to the tune of approximately €620,000 plus benefits, which would bring him close to €900,000. Mr. Boucher is probably in line for a pension of the order of €400,000. He is clearly well prepared on a PR level to answer no questions. Where is his moral compass in all of this? The problem is that Bank of Ireland sold products during the boom that people could not afford.
Is Deputy O’Donnell making a concluding comment or putting a question?
I am putting a question and then a final comment.
The Deputy should put his question.

The question is whether the bank will deal with mortgage holders to ensure their mortgages are sustainable. The second question is important. It has not been asked previously. How much of the €3.5 billion target for lending to SMEs was new lending not restructured lending?
The question was asked by Deputy O’Donnell’s colleague, Deputy Dara Murphy.
New and increased lending amounted to €3.5 billion.
No, just new lending. I am not interested in restructured lending.
I have said we do not count restructured lending in our targets. We do not get revenue from restructured loans.
When AIB was before the committee yesterday it informed us that €600 million of the €3.5 billion was completely new lending, not restructured lending.
We are not AIB.
I am asking Mr. Boucher a question.
It was €3.5 billion.
So €3.5 billion was completely new lending.
This is a public disclosure. I am conscious of my public disclosures.
Is Mr. Boucher saying that none of it was restructured.

Some of it may be but to a statistical margin of error, which in our view is less than 3%. I can say with confidence that 97% of the total is new lending. I believe it is 100% but I cannot verify that. This is a market disclosure. Any comments I make in a public forum are market disclosures.
Mr. Boucher is saying that €3.5 billion is completely new lending.
It is new and increased lending.
Could Mr. Boucher tell me about the mortgage holders?
Deputy O’Donnell-----
Will Bank of Ireland engage in the restructuring-----
Excuse me. The Chair is speaking to Deputy O’Donnell.
In the limited time-----
I do not care about the limited time. As soon as I open my mouth Deputy O’Donnell should stop talking. If he can make the point succinctly I will allow it.
Will Bank of Ireland engage in the restructuring of mortgages and will Mr. Boucher take a reduction in salary and will-----
That is a second question. I am moving on.
These are important questions.
I am moving on.
What about the question on mortgage holders?
Deputy O’Donnell must please respect the Chair.
We are engaging every day with mortgage holders to restructure and modify their loans.
Will Mr. Boucher take a reduction in his salary?
My salary is put to the shareholders.

That question has been put before. The Gallery has heard it enough this morning. Before I bring in Deputy Shane Ross, Mr. Boucher must clarify a few points. There has been wide acceptance that his engagement with the committee on a number of questions has been at a minimalist level, if I could even call it that. I wish to put that on record.

An issue has been outstanding since Mr. Boucher came before the committee and I still have not got my head around it. A question was put to Mr. Boucher, as it was put to AIB, on the absolute cost of the institution reducing the standard variable rate on domestic mortgages by 0.5%. The figure we got from AIB yesterday afternoon was that private dwelling houses on its domestic book is worth approximately €14.3 billion and a 0.5% reduction would result in a loss of €71 million to AIB. On the figures Mr. Boucher gave us this morning, the domestic book of Bank of Ireland is approximately €21 billion and if the bank reduced its standard variable rate by 0.5% its loss would be €29 million, approximately a third less than AIB. Could he explain to us how it is the case that a smaller loss would be incurred following a 0.5% reduction given that the loan book is bigger?

The trackers are excluded. We have fixed-rate mortgages and standard variable-rate mortgages. We disclose the trackers. With regard to the standard rate and variable rate, our figure may be lower than that of Allied Irish Banks, but I am not familiar with the numbers of the latter.
As far as I know, there is blending also.
We have fixed-rate mortgages in addition to standard variable-rate mortgages.

Another issue relates to a question put to Mr. Boucher by Deputy Donnelly. Yesterday afternoon, AIB was asked the number of mortgages with a shortfall that it has allowed to be surrendered voluntarily and its policy on shortfalls. We seem to have received a very vague response from Bank of Ireland on the matter. The AIB officials advised us yesterday afternoon that 140 properties were surrendered with a mortgage shortfall. The response of Bank of Ireland to date has been that it has a responsibility to maximise the recovery of all moneys owed by customers and that it has a comprehensive arrangement and process to work with customers to find solutions that can work for them and the bank in this regard. Bank of Ireland states that, as a last resort, it may have to instigate a formal legal process. That is not answering the question; rather, it is symptomatic of some of the replies we received this morning. It indicates the bank is not really engaging with the process in a serious manner. It also means it is not engaging with this committee in a serious manner, which is of equal concern to me. What is Bank of Ireland's position on the issue of voluntary surrenders where there are mortgage shortfalls? What is the bank doing in this regard?
The total number of repossessions or surrenders for the half-year was 200.
I have a figure of approximately 120.
There is a mixture of owner-occupier and buy-to-let properties.

Why could the delegates not have given us that answer at the start of this morning's proceedings without our having to endure a lengthy rigmarole? The question was put to the delegates very simply and we now have the answer.
I am sorry if I missed that specific question.
There is a big X across it. It is a market disclosure.

Mr. Boucher has still not answered the question that specifically concerns surrender. The delegation listed a total number of surrenders or repossessions but did not answer the question on the level of debt surrender involved.
Could Mr. Boucher answer that?
We deal with customers on an individual basis and therefore do not disclose the figures.
Bank of Ireland does disclose them. Mr. Boucher disclosed the figures to us before. He is treating this committee with contempt today.
I am not.
He most certainly is.
I am not. I must conform with the requirements of the Stock Exchange on disclosures.
Is Mr. Boucher telling me that, by law, he is not allowed to tell this committee how much he has or has not surrendered?
I am conforming with the requirements I have in the Stock Exchange.
Is that an interpretation or did Mr. Boucher get a legal ruling?
I do not have lawyers sitting beside me when answering every question.
Have the guidelines changed since Bank of Ireland provided us with the information on the last occasion?
I have given the answer I can give.
Mr. Boucher is very welcome. I declare an interest in that I am a small shareholder in Bank of Ireland.
Is Mr. Boucher a member of the board?
Yes.
How did the board choose the new governor?

We have a nominations and governance committee. It went to an external third party, which identified potential candidates. The potential candidates were reviewed by the committee and a recommendation was put to the board. When the candidate agreed to be considered, there was consultation with the FSA, because we have a large business, and then the candidate went through the process to meet the fitness and probity requirements of the Central Bank of Ireland.
How much did Mr. Boucher know about the prospective new governor when his name was submitted to the board?
There was full disclosure of all issues that were considered to be relevant.
This is important because the appointee is, I believe, on €400,000 per year. Was Mr. Boucher aware of his record in Lloyds TSB?
There was full disclosure of his entire career.
Was Mr. Boucher aware that he was the insurance director?
Yes.
Was Mr. Boucher aware that he was insurance director during the biggest scandal pertaining to payment protection insurance that has ever arisen in the United Kingdom?
He was a director of Lloyds Bank and was in charge of the insurance division.
Was Mr. Boucher aware that there was a huge scandal pertaining to payment protection insurance while the individual was in charge?
We were well aware of the disclosures that Lloyds had made.
Was that disclosure made?
Lloyds had made its disclosures prior to the appointment of the chairman.
Was Mr. Boucher aware of the insurance mis-selling scandal that was breaking?
In its annual report, Lloyds Bank had disclosed-----
Was Mr. Boucher aware of it? I know about Lloyds Bank.
We would read the annual report.
Was Mr. Boucher aware of it?
We were aware of the disclosures that Lloyds Bank made regarding payment protection insurance.
Was Mr. Boucher happy to appoint someone who had been accountable when mis-selling was occurring?
Deputy Ross is starting to make certain inferences.
I am not inferring anything; it is on the public record.
Deputy Ross is doing so.

It is on the public record. Lloyds stated that accountability was important. When making the appointment, was Mr. Boucher aware that the individual's bonus was reduced as a result of what had occurred?
Yes. As I stated, there was full disclosure.

Mr. Boucher, therefore, was happy to appoint someone who lost a bonus in a bank, which, as Mr. Boucher will know, is very difficult to do. I refer to the appointment, as governor of Bank of Ireland, of an individual who lost a bonus at the time of an emerging mis-selling scandal. Today, it has been revealed that the payment protection insurance bill of Lloyds has ballooned to €5.3 billion. Is Mr. Boucher aware of that?
Yes.
Yet Bank of Ireland still appointed the person as governor.
We made the appointment bearing in mind the full disclosures, the references we received and the fitness and probity regime of the Central Bank of Ireland, and we did so in consultation with the FSA.
Is Mr. Boucher happy that Bank of Ireland has a governor who is fit for office in the circumstances that obtain?
Yes.
What is the current position of Bank of Ireland on payment protection insurance?
We are carrying out a review of payment protection.
Has there been mis-selling?
A review will determine whether there was.
What is Mr. Boucher's view on that?
We are having a review; that is what we are doing.
It is widely expected that a massive amount of mis-selling of payment protection insurance in Ireland, including by Bank of Ireland, will be revealed. What is Mr. Boucher's view on that?

We must examine the total quantum of payment protection insurance policies that Bank of Ireland sold. If there was any mis-selling, it would be serious, but, based on any information available to me, we do not have a market disclosure requirement.

It is absolutely extraordinary that Bank of Ireland should appoint as a governor somebody who had lost his bonus in Lloyds in a payment protection insurance scandal. There are now circumstances in which the bank is investigating itself in respect of payment protection insurance. The board made its appointment in the full awareness that the individual concerned, while not necessarily culpable, was the director in charge of insurance when the scandal arose. That should be noted by this committee.
I thank Mr. Boucher, Ms Carragher and Mr. McLoughlin for appearing before the committee for the third of our modules on banking, which we have considered over the past two days.

debateSection.summary: The joint committee adjourned at 1.20 p.m. until 2 p.m. on Wednesday, 7 November 2012.
